awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Assessment of a Frozen Archaeology Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a small RAPID award for PI Susan Kaplan to take advantage of a Parks Canada vessel and polar bear monitors free of charge for two weeks fieldwork in northern Labrador, Canada.  This project will be a stability assessment of a Middle Dorset (800 CE to 1,000 CE; CE meaning Common Era or the equivalent of 1,216 years ago to 1,016 years ago) archaeological site (Avayalik-1) 25 miles south of the tip of Labrador.

Worldwide archaeological heritage is under threat from environmental change; in the Arctic this is manifested as sea level rise and the accompanying storm surges eating way at coastal sites. As in other places in the Arctic, Avayalik-1 permafrost is melting causing changes in hydrology and the deterioration of fragile organic artifacts and faunal remains. This investigation will assess the vulnerability of archaeological sites in permafrost, which will contribute to discussions on how to assess, monitor, and preserve such sites. This information is of great interest to the scientific community, culture resource managers but also to the indigenous residents who are in many cases the decedents of the original occupants.

Avayalik-1 is a scientifically unique site of Middle Dorset (pre Thule culture, the ancestors of modern Inuit people).  Avayalik-1, last investigated in 1978, yielded organic artifacts and faunal remains unsurpassed in quantity and preservation by any other Labrador Middle Dorset sites due to the fact the ground was permanently frozen.  However, with the current state of the Arctic and the rapidly thawing permafrost, many Arctic heritage sites thought for decades to be not endangered are now under threat.  Avayalik-1 is such a site. 

This important project will assist archaeologists and culture heritage managers in determining whether the Avayalik-1 site is endangered, which would signal a potential loss of a critical Paleo-Inuit environmental and cultural record. In addition, new archaeometric and data techniques will be applied to the soil samples taken from the site, techniques not available in 1978 when the site was last studied. This data will help in assessing the full potential of the site for contributing to our understanding of how people have adapted to life in challenging environment sand how the ecology of the maritime North Atlantic has changed over time.

por.por_cntn:
This RAPID award supported the work of three archaeologists who conducted two weeks of fieldwork in northern Labrador, Canada. The goal of the fieldwork was to assess the stability of Avayalik-1, an important prehistoric (Middle Dorset) archaeology site occupied about 1,216 years ago and located on an outer island 25 miles south of the tip of Labrador, Newfoundland-Labrador, Canada. Considered remote today, the island was occupied by people who appear to have been in the center of a group of thriving seasonal settlements that carried out a lively trade involving raw materials and possibly finished goods.

In addition to NSF funding, Parks Canada provided the project a boat, its crew, and a polar bear monitor free of charge. Bowdoin College provided the equipment, and the College and funds from Kane Lodge Foundation, Inc. provided additional support. The work was conducted under Parks Canada Torngat Mountains National Park permit TMNP 2016-22216 and was carried out in collaboration with Parks Canada and the Nunatsiavut Government. 

Worldwide coastal archaeology sites are being destroyed due to environmental change. In the Arctic, rising sea levels and ocean storms are eating way at coastal heritage sites. Also, soils that have been frozen for centuries (permafrost), preserving prehistoric houses and artifacts fashioned from organic materials such as bone, ivory, fur, and wood, are thawing. Any object not made out of stone is in danger of deteriorating as the region warms. As soils slump, the prehistoric structures built on the eroding surfaces are in danger as well.

This project involved visiting and assessing the condition of Avayalik-1, a site that was found to have frozen cultural deposits in 1978. Archaeologists excavated a portion of the site in 1978 and recovered quantities of extraordinary organic artifacts never before found in other Labrador prehistoric sites. Artifacts recovered included a wooden maskette; stitched hide; musk ox cordage; bone, wood, and ivory implements; knotted baleen; possible components of a shaman’s kit, and quantities of wood, stone, baleen, and bone debris. The site also provided evidence of a North Atlantic ecosystem quite different from the one we know today.

The archaeologists who visited the site in 2016 determined that Avayalik-1 is now in danger. They conducted foot surveys of the island and found evidence of melting permafrost and coastal erosion in many locations. They observed the edges of the main terrace on which Avayalik-1 is located eroding and soils tumbling downslope, spilling artifacts onto the ground. The archaeologists closely examined a small cove southwest of Avayalik-1, House 1 and found artifacts eroding out of sods and falling onto the cove floor where they are washed away by the tides.

Water from thawing permafrost was observed pooling in some sections of the terrace, while in others it was observed running downslope from under the turf and sodded areas. Avayalik-1, House I was tested and its cultural deposits are no longer frozen. However organic and stone artifacts, as well as the remains of insects and plants were recovered, suggesting the site still contains important cultural and environmental information that should be excavated and analyzed before the organic materials deteriorate further.

The 2016 team located six additional suspected buried house structures at Avayalik-1 in the vicinity of House 1. Two were tested and frozen cultural deposits were encountered in both test pits. Some of the other structures likely contain frozen deposits as well. Two of those structures are in danger as they are adjacent to the actively eroding edge of the small southwestern cove discussed above.

The team accomplished everything it set out to do. They determined that important structures and cultural deposits on the island are in danger due to the thawing of permafrost and coastal erosion. They recovered wood and charcoal that will hopefully provide a more refined set of dates of Avayalik-1’s prehistoric occupations, got a good sense of the state of preservation of artifacts in those deposits, and identified additional structures that should help shed light on the cultural and environmental history of the island and of northern Labrador. Given the importance of this site, the researchers have recommended that it should be excavated before its unique contents are lost forever.

In addition to providing valuable information on the condition of the Avayalik-1 site, the work generated information on efficient ways to assess sites to determine their vulnerability. This work has been shared with other archaeologists working in the Arctic, as well as cultural heritage managers employed by the Province of Newfoundland-Labrador, the Nunatsiavut Government, and Parks Canada.
